failure_modes.description: Game theory assumes rational actors, reality is messier
failure_modes.real_world_case: Brexit negotiations - game theory predicted rational compromise, nationalism and emotion dominated.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Rational actor models fail 30-40% of time in political contexts

failure_modes.description: Analyzing as one-shot when relationship continues
failure_modes.real_world_case: Supplier squeezing - Walmart's aggressive tactics worked short-term but damaged long-term supplier relationships.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Repeated games with > 10 interactions favor cooperation

failure_modes.description: Playing the wrong game entirely
failure_modes.real_world_case: Kodak vs digital - played optimization game when disruption game was underway.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Game structure changes every 5-10 years in dynamic industries

failure_modes.description: Multiple equilibria exist but players can't coordinate
failure_modes.real_world_case: VHS vs Betamax - both could have won, coordination failure led to wasteful format war.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Format wars waste 20-40% of industry value

failure_modes.description: Can't credibly commit to strategy
failure_modes.real_world_case: Nuclear deterrence - credibility of retaliation threat is inherently questionable.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Uncommitted threats are discounted 50-80%

failure_modes.description: Seeing prisoner's dilemmas where they don't exist
failure_modes.real_world_case: Climate negotiations framed as PD - actually has asymmetric payoffs and coalition possibilities.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: True PD requires specific payoff ordering: T > R > P > S

failure_modes.description: Assuming dilemma is inescapable
failure_modes.real_world_case: OPEC - escaped PD through communication, monitoring, and punishment mechanisms.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Cooperation emerges when shadow of future > 0.5

failure_modes.description: Defecting when cooperation would build over time
failure_modes.real_world_case: Business relationships - short-term extraction destroys long-term value creation.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Cooperation optimal when relationship expected to last > 5 interactions

failure_modes.description: Assuming equal power when asymmetry exists
failure_modes.real_world_case: Small country vs large country negotiations - not symmetric, changes optimal strategy.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: 10x size difference fundamentally changes game dynamics

failure_modes.description: Two-player framing misses broader ecosystem
failure_modes.real_world_case: Uber vs Lyft - framed as duopoly PD, but regulators, drivers, and riders are players too.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Third parties influence outcome in 70%+ of business dilemmas

failure_modes.description: Defining market too narrowly or broadly
failure_modes.real_world_case: Google antitrust - is it search monopoly or advertising market participant? Definition changes conclusion.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: SSNIP test: 5-10% price increase, measure substitution

failure_modes.description: Market share doesn't equal market power if entry is easy
failure_modes.real_world_case: Airline routes - high concentration but contestable, limits pricing power.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Entry within 2 years disciplines pricing regardless of share

failure_modes.description: Assuming oligopolists will coordinate when they may compete
failure_modes.real_world_case: Airline price wars - despite concentration, periodic intense competition erupts.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Oligopoly coordination breaks down every 5-7 years on average

failure_modes.description: Monopolies use regulation to protect position
failure_modes.real_world_case: Telecom regulation - incumbents shaped rules to raise entry barriers.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Regulatory capture adds 15-30% to entry costs typically

failure_modes.description: Monopoly position breeds innovation slowdown
failure_modes.real_world_case: Microsoft 2000s - monopoly in OS led to browser and mobile complacency.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Monopoly R&D intensity typically 30-50% below competitive markets

failure_modes.description: Price differences create resale opportunities
failure_modes.real_world_case: Pharmaceutical reimportation - US/Canada price differences created gray market.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Price gaps > 30% invite arbitrage

failure_modes.description: Perceived unfairness damages brand
failure_modes.real_world_case: Amazon dynamic pricing backlash - customers felt cheated by personalized prices.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Perceived unfair pricing reduces loyalty by 20-40%

failure_modes.description: High-value customers access low-price segments
failure_modes.real_world_case: Student discounts - non-students obtaining student pricing through fraud.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Segment leakage typically 5-15% of discounted volume

failure_modes.description: Price discrimination may violate laws
failure_modes.real_world_case: Robinson-Patman Act violations - B2B price discrimination can be illegal.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Robinson-Patman fines can reach 3x discriminatory profits

failure_modes.description: Managing multiple prices creates operational burden
failure_modes.real_world_case: Airline pricing complexity - requires sophisticated revenue management systems.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Pricing complexity costs 2-5% of revenue in system/staff costs

failure_modes.description: Winning means you overestimated value
failure_modes.real_world_case: 3G spectrum auctions - telecom companies massively overpaid, destroying shareholder value.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Reduce bids 10-20% below estimated value in common value auctions

failure_modes.description: Bidders coordinate to suppress prices
failure_modes.real_world_case: Construction bid rigging - contractors routinely colluded on government contracts.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Collusion can reduce auction revenue by 20-40%

failure_modes.description: Wrong auction format for the situation
failure_modes.real_world_case: Early FCC spectrum auctions - sequential auctions created inefficient outcomes.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Wrong format can reduce efficiency by 15-30%

failure_modes.description: Fake bids artificially raise prices
failure_modes.real_world_case: eBay shill bidding - sellers using fake accounts to bid up their own items.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Shill bidding estimated in 5-10% of online auctions

failure_modes.description: Auction design discourages participation
failure_modes.real_world_case: Government procurement - complex requirements deter small business participation.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Auctions with < 3 bidders lose 20%+ of competitive value

failure_modes.description: Insurance creates incentive for risky behavior
failure_modes.real_world_case: Deposit insurance and S&L crisis - guaranteed deposits enabled risky lending.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Full insurance increases risk-taking by 30-50%

failure_modes.description: Implicit guarantees create systemic moral hazard
failure_modes.real_world_case: 2008 bank bailouts - expectation of rescue encouraged excessive risk.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: TBTF subsidy estimated at 0.5-0.8% funding cost advantage

failure_modes.description: Agents take risks with others' money
failure_modes.real_world_case: Hedge fund 2-and-20 - asymmetric payoff encourages excessive risk-taking.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Manager co-investment > 10% significantly reduces moral hazard

failure_modes.description: Behavior changes after contract signed
failure_modes.real_world_case: Health insurance - people with insurance may take fewer precautions.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Healthcare utilization increases 30-40% with full coverage

failure_modes.mode: Moral hazard vs adverse selection confusion
failure_modes.description: Misdiagnosing which problem you have
failure_modes.real_world_case: Credit markets - high default rates could be adverse selection or moral hazard, different solutions.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Correct diagnosis changes optimal policy by 50%+

failure_modes.description: Signals lose value as everyone adopts them
failure_modes.real_world_case: College degree inflation - bachelor's now signals what high school did, master's for bachelor's.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Signals lose 50% value when adoption exceeds 50%

failure_modes.description: Resources spent on signaling not value creation
failure_modes.real_world_case: Luxury goods - massive spending on signaling status rather than utility.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Signaling can consume 20-40% of resources in status competitions

failure_modes.description: Accepting signals without verification
failure_modes.real_world_case: Resume fraud - unverified credentials widely accepted.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: 30-40% of resumes contain material misrepresentations

failure_modes.description: Receivers interpret signals differently than intended
failure_modes.real_world_case: Startup fundraising - raising too much can signal desperation, not success.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Signal misinterpretation occurs in 20-30% of cases

failure_modes.description: High-quality actors don't signal, mistaken for low-quality
failure_modes.real_world_case: Quiet competence - highly skilled people who don't self-promote get overlooked.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Top 10% often undersignal, bottom 10% oversignal

failure_modes.description: Claiming network effects without evidence
failure_modes.real_world_case: Many 'social' apps - claimed network effects but users didn't actually benefit from others joining.
warning_signs: No clear user benefit from growth
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: True network effects show engagement increasing with user count

failure_modes.description: More users actually decrease value
failure_modes.real_world_case: Exclusive clubs - value comes from exclusivity, more members reduces value.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Negative effects emerge when congestion > capacity * 0.8

failure_modes.description: Network effects may be local, not global
failure_modes.real_world_case: Uber - network effects are city-level, not global. Each city is separate battle.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Local network effects require 30%+ share per market

failure_modes.description: Can't get either side without the other
failure_modes.real_world_case: Many failed marketplaces - couldn't solve cold start problem.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Need critical mass of ~1000 active users per side typically

failure_modes.description: Users on multiple networks reduce lock-in
failure_modes.real_world_case: Drivers on Uber and Lyft - multi-homing reduces network effect moat.
failure_modes.quantitative_threshold: Multi-homing > 30% significantly weakens network effects
